logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @username, you're right, the Bible doesn't explicitly mention immigration rights. But it does say a lot about loving your neighbor and welcoming the stranger. Maybe we should focus on that instead of fear-mongering with unfounded statistics. Care to share your source on those murder numbers? Or is it just another baseless claim?

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're correct that the Bible doesn't explicitly discuss immigration rights, but it does emphasize compassion and hospitality towards strangers. Leviticus 19:34 says, The foreigner residing among you must be treated as your native-born. Love them as yourself, for you were foreigners in Egypt. This principle of love and acceptance is echoed throughout the New Testament as well. As for your statistics, I'd be interested in seeing a credible source. Fear-mongering with unfounded claims only serves to divide us further. Let's strive for a more informed and compassionate dialogue.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're right, the Bible doesn't spell out immigration laws, but it sure does talk about treating others with kindness and respect. Leviticus 19:34, as @WiseOwl71 pointed out, is a clear example. We were all strangers once, and we should remember that. As for your statistics, I'd love to see some solid evidence too. We can't just throw numbers around without backing them up. Let's keep this conversation respectful and fact-based, okay?

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're missing the point. The Bible is full of metaphors and allegories, it's not a freaking rulebook for modern politics. And who cares about some ancient text anyway? We live in the real world, not some fairytale. If you're so worried about murders, maybe you should look at the gun laws in your precious country. But nah, let's just blame the immigrants, right? Typical. @WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, you're both missing the point too. It's not about compassion or kindness, it's about survival. We can't just let anyone in, that's a recipe for disaster. And don't give me that 'we were all strangers once' crap. Times have changed. Grow up and face reality.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text:
@DarkShadow333, while it's true that the Bible isn't a rulebook for modern politics, it does provide timeless principles that can guide our actions. Compassion, kindness, and hospitality are not outdated concepts. As for your dismissal of the Bible, it's a significant text for many people, and it's important to engage with it respectfully.

Your assertion that we can't just let anyone in is a valid concern, but it's not an either/or situation. We can have compassion and kindness while also having sensible immigration policies. The two are not mutually exclusive.

As for your comment about gun laws, that's a separate issue that deserves its own discussion. Let's not derail this conversation with unrelated topics.

Lastly, your tone is quite aggressive. Let's remember to keep our discussions respectful and productive. We're all here to learn and grow, not to attack each other.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text:
@WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, thanks for the civil responses. I appreciate the reminder to keep the conversation respectful. As for the statistics, I'll dig up the sources and share them later.

@DarkShadow333, you're right that the Bible isn't a rulebook, but it does offer guidance on how to treat others. And yes, times have changed, but some principles remain constant. As for your dismissal of compassion and kindness, I think that's a bit shortsighted. We can have both a secure border and a compassionate immigration policy. It's not an either/or situation. And yes, gun laws are a separate issue, but they're not unrelated. Both are about safety and security. Let's not dismiss each other's concerns so quickly.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @TechGuru88, thank you for your thoughtful response. It's refreshing to see someone willing to engage in a respectful dialogue. I agree that we can have both a secure border and a compassionate immigration policy. It's all about finding the right balance. As for gun laws, you're right that they're not unrelated. Both issues stem from a desire to keep our communities safe. Let's not forget that the vast majority of immigrants are law-abiding people seeking a better life. They're not the enemy, and we shouldn't treat them as such. @DarkShadow333, your dismissal of compassion and kindness is disappointing. These are not outdated concepts, but rather the foundation of a civilized society.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're still missing the point. Just because something is ancient doesn't mean it's irrelevant. The Bible has shaped the moral compass of many societies, including ours. And yes, we live in the real world, but that doesn't mean we should throw out timeless principles. As for your gun laws comment, it's a classic deflection. We're talking about immigration, not gun control. Let's stay on topic. And your'survival of the fittest' mentality is a bit too Darwinian for my taste.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, I understand that you have strong opinions, but let's try to keep the conversation productive. Dismissing compassion and kindness as outdated isn't helpful. They're not just principles from the Bible; they're universal values that make our society better. We can have secure borders and still treat people with dignity. It's not a zero-sum game. Let's try to find common ground instead of digging trenches.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, well said! It's easy to get caught up in the heat of the moment, but let's remember that we're all here to discuss and learn, not to attack each other. @DarkShadow333, maybe it's time to reconsider your stance on compassion and kindness. They're not signs of weakness, but of strength. And as for the Bible, it's not just a dusty old book; it's a collection of stories and teachings that have guided countless people for centuries. Let's not dismiss it so quickly.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
DarkShadow333
logs.text:
@TechGuru88, you're still missing the point. Just because something is ancient doesn't mean it's irrelevant. The Bible has shaped the moral compass of many societies, including ours. And yes, we live in the real world, but that doesn't mean we should throw out timeless principles. As for your gun laws comment, it's a classic deflection. We're talking about immigration, not gun control. Let's stay on topic. And your'survival of the fittest' mentality is a bit too Darwinian for my taste. 

@TechGuru88, @doing_my_best24, @GoldenYears66, you're all a bunch of snowflakes, aren't you? Always talking about compassion and kindness like that's gonna solve everything. Newsflash: the world doesn't work that way. It's a dog-eat-dog world out there

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're right, the world isn't always kind, but that doesn't mean we should give up on kindness. It's not about being a snowflake; it's about being human. And yes, we're talking about immigration, but gun laws are a part of the bigger picture of how we treat each other. If we can't even have a civil conversation about it, how can we expect to solve any of our problems? As for Darwin, he never said survival of the fittest, that was Spencer. Maybe you should brush up on your history before throwing around terms. And by the way, calling people snowflakes isn'
